<ol start="18">
<li>
<p>Oral sex is not recommended for mother during their postpartum period because of:
a) Possible abdominal pain
b) Infection to the spouse
c) Embolism due to blowing air in to uterus
d) Pain in the perineum</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The possible congenital problem that may result from a ovum that is fertilized by more than one sperm is:
a) Blastocyst
b) Hydatidiform mole
c) Mongolism
d) Intra uterine growth restriction</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A midwife should expect a woman who develops deep venous thrombosis to be given heparin sodium to:-
a) Prevent further enlargement of the vein
b) Reduce calf tissue oedema
c) Improve the venous return
d) Dissolve the thrombosis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>First stage of labour is defined as a period from onset of:-
a) Labour pains to full dilatation
b) Labour pains to full crowning of the head
c) True labour to birth of the baby
d) True labour to full dilation of the cervix</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A condition in which a midwife prepares a mother for emergency cesarean section include:-
a) Previous cesarean section
b) Cord presentation
c) Twin pregnancy
d) Meconium stained amniotic fluid</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A woman had rupture of the membranes 24 hours prior to birth, the midwife should assess this mother for:-
a) Elevate temperatures
b) Proteinuria
c) Chorioamnitis
d) Persistent drainage of liquor</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Administration of magnesium sulphate in pregnancy is known to have the following advantages: -
a) Reduces the rate of respiratory distress, Neural tube protection, maternal convulsions
b) Reduces the rate of cerebral palsy, Neural tube protection, intraventricular hemorrhage
c) Reduces the rate of cerebral palsy, Neural tube protection, maternal convulsions
d) Reduces the rate of preterm labor, Neural tube protection, maternal convulsions</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The following is the best way to diagnose invasive placenta like placenta percreta
a) Magnetic Resonance Imaging
b) Trans Vaginal Ultrasound
c) Trans Abdominal Ultrasound
d) Clinical features</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The major cause of antepartum hemorrhage includes: -
a) Placenta previa, placenta abruption, uterine curettage, ruptured vasa previa
b) Placenta previa, previous placenta abruption, uterine rupture, ruptured vasa previa
c) Placenta previa, placenta abruption, uterine rupture, uterine fibroids
d) Placenta previa, placenta abruption, uterine rupture, ruptured vasa previa</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>KMTC/QP-8/EPS</p>
<ol start="26">
<li>
<p>The following are the possible obstetric causes of cardiac arrest in pregnancy:
a) Amniotic fluid embolism, eclampsia, magnesium toxicity, postpartum hemorrhage
b) Thromboembolism, sepsis, cerebrovascular accident, myocardial infarction
c) Amniotic fluid embolism, eclampsia, magnesium toxicity, aortic dissection
d) Thromboembolism, magnesium toxicity, cerebrovascular accident, myocardial infarction</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Delayed cord clamping for one to three minutes after birth of baby:
a) Allows blood in cord and placenta to push pumped to the mother
b) Increase the risk of transmission of HIV from mother to child
c) Increase the risk of PPH
d) Decreases neonatal risk of anaemia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>How frequent should the fetal heart rate be assessed for a mother in second stage?
a) After every 15 minutes
b) After every contraction
c) After every 30 minutes
d) Not of any importance for the fetus is almost out</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The nursing diagnosis that would be given priority in the care plan of a newborn at one hour age is
a) Risk for infection
b) Ineffective thermoregulation
c) Impaired skin integrity
d) Altered nutrition</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The most common cause of maternal death in Kenya is:
a) Malaria
b) Infection
c) Hemorrhage
d) Toxaemia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The laboratory test likely to be omitted from the routine antenatal care without jeopardizing the health of the mother and fetus is:
a) Serological test for syphilis
b) Blood type/Rhesus determination
c) Urinalysis for albumin and sugar
d) Blood urea and nitrogen</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The temporary structure in the fetal circulation that shunts blood around the lungs is called?
a) Ductus arteriosus
b) Ductus venosus
c) Foramen ovale
d) Ligamentum venosus</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The features of the gynaecoid pelvis that allow it to be adequate for vaginal birth is:
a) Prominent ischial spines and wide fore pelvis
b) Sciatic notch and divergent side walls
c) Rounded brim and straight side walls
d) Oval brim and blunt ischial spines</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In atypical vertex presentation the sequence of events by which the fetal ead adopts to the birth canal is:
a) Lateral flexion, descent, internal rotation, external rotation.
b) Flexion, descent, restitution, lateral flexion
c) Descent, flexion, internal rotation, extension
d) Descent, lateral flexion, shoulder rotation, restitution</p>
</li>
</ol>

</li>

a) Respiratory distress syndrome, hypoglycaemia
b) Respiratory distress syndrome, hyperglycaemia
c) Respiratory distress syndrome, hypercalcaemia

a) Kigels, immunization, nutrition, hygiene
b) Resume coitus, danger signs, hygiene, perineum care

</li>
<li>

a) Change of position/ moving around, orgasm birthing, breathing techniques, warm bath
b) Sacral massage from a companion, orgasm birthing, side lying, warm bath

</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="section-1-multiple-choice-questions">SECTION 1: MULTIPLE CHOICE QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-1-multiple-choice-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(40 MARKS)</p>
<ol>
<li>The communication process can be influenced by various factors that affect how the message is received and interpreted. The factors that affect communication process to the receiver include:</li>
</ol>
<p>A. Knowledge, experience, defense mechanism
B. Motivation, mood, language
C. Physical condition, attention, intensity
D. Movement, repetition, mood</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>When taking blood pressure, the point at which the first sound is heard or felt is referred to as the:</li>
</ol>
<p>A. Diastolic pressure
B. Systemic pressure
C. Systolic pressure
D. Diastole and systole pressure</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Pressure sores also known as bedsores or decubitus ulcers can be prevented by the following measures:</li>
</ol>
<p>A. Relieving pressure, improving circulation, keeping the skin dry
B. Improving circulation, good nutrition, dry skin
C. Relieving pressure, ambulation, application of Vaseline
D. Application of powder, good nutrition, relieving pressure</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Liver biopsy is contraindicated in patients with one of the following conditions:</li>
</ol>
<p>A. Liver disease
B. Anaemia
C. Bleeding disorder
D. Blood dyscrasias</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>State whether the following statements are true or false</li>
</ol>
<p>A. After lumbar puncture, the nurse should observe for bleeding or swelling of the puncture site.
B. Bone marrow biopsy is indicated for disorders of the bones</p>
<ol start="6">
<li>The correct sequence of decontamination of instruments typically involves the following steps:</li>
</ol>
<p>A. Soak in soapy water, soak in bleach solution, clean with water, air dry
B. Air dry, soak in bleach solution, clean with water, put in soapy
C. Soak in bleach solution, soak in soapy water, air drying, put in clean water.
D. Soak in bleach solution, put in soapy water, clean with water, air dry.</p>
<ol start="7">
<li>According to the Integrated Management of Childhood Illness (IMCI) protocol, the management of pneumonia in a child requires follow-up care to monitor recovery and identify any potential complications. The child should be followed up in:</li>
</ol>
<p>A. Seven days
B. Five days
C. Three days
D. Two days</p>
<p>Page 2 of 8</p>
<p>KMTC/QP-08/EPS</p>
<ol start="8">
<li>Severe dehydration in a child with diarrhea is characterized by the following signs:</li>
</ol>
<p>A. Sunken eyes, unable to drink, lethargy
B. Poor skin turgor, irritability, sunken eyes
C. Restless, poor skin turgor, irritability.
D. Blood in stool, sunken eyes, restless</p>
<ol start="9">
<li>Assessment in the nursing process involves the systematic collection of information to identify their health needs and problems. It is the first and critical step in the nursing process and includes the following components:</li>
</ol>
<p>A. Data collection, organizing data, data validation
B. Data analysis, documentation, selection of nursing interventions.
C. Organizing data, implementing nursing interventions, problem prioritizing
D. Validating data, organizing data, formulating diagnostic statement.</p>
<ol start="10">
<li>A nursing diagnosis for a patient experiencing an asthmatic attack would typically focus on the patient's respiratory function and the impact of the asthma exacerbation on their overall health. A common nursing diagnosis for this situation might be:</li>
</ol>
<p>A. Dyspnoea, chest pain, cyanosis, fluid deficit.
B. Impaired airway clearance, ineffective tissue perfusion, impaired chest discomfort.
C. Altered body temperature, body weakness, impaired tissue perfusion.
D. Impaired airway clearance, dyspnoea, fluid deficit.</p>
<ol start="11">
<li>Complications of diabetes mellitus can be serious and affect various systems in the body. They are often categorized into acute and chronic complications and may include:</li>
</ol>
<p>A. Renal failure, diabetic foot, ketoacidosis.
B. Retinopathy, hyperglycemia, renal failures
C. Peripheral neuropathy, retinopathy, hypoglycemia
D. Myocardial infarction, diabetic foot, peripheral neuropathy</p>
<ol start="12">
<li>After an appendicectomy, the nurse's role is crucial in preventing potential complications and ensuring proper recovery. Your interventions include:</li>
</ol>
<p>A. Monitoring for abdominal tenderness, fever, vomiting, tachycardia.
B. Taking blood pressure, providing plenty of fluids.
C. Bed rest, providing antibiotics, relieving pain.
D. Assessing for chills, fever, fluid monitoring.</p>
<ol start="13">
<li>Peritonitis can be a life-threatening condition. The clinical manifestations of peritonitis vary in severity but generally include:</li>
</ol>
<p>A. Diffuse pain, rebound tenderness, headache
B. Tenderness, paralytic ileus, dehydration.
C. Rebound, tenderness, dehydration, fever.
D. Paralytic ileus, tenderness, diffuse pain</p>
<ol start="14">
<li>Polymenorrhea is a medical term used to describe</li>
</ol>
<p>A. Painful excessive menstrual flow
B. Absence of menstruation.
C. Excessive menstrual flow
D. Inadequate and irregular menstruation.</p>
<p>Page 3 of 8</p>
<p>KMTC/QP-08/EPS</p>
<ol start="15">
<li>
<p>The goals of medical management of herpes zoster primarily focus on:
A. Relieve pain and avoid complications
B. Provide nutritional diet and early referral
C. Regular observation of vital signs and antibiotic therapy.
D. Corticosteroid therapy and provision of broad spectrum antibiotics.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The correct procedure is of eye swabbing is:
A. From the unaffected eye from the inner canthus to the outer canthus
B. Affected eye from outer canthus towards the inner canthus.
C. From eyelids to the inner canthus to the outer canthus
D. From the unaffected eye from the outer canthus towards the inner canthus.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The most common method used to measure visual acuity is through:
A. Ophthalmoscope
B. Snennel chart
C. Pinhole and pointer
D. Torch and eye lens</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Epistaxis can occur due to a variety of underlying factors, and recognizing risk factors can help in both prevention and management. These factors include:
A. Hypertension, use of aspirin, liver disease
B. Thrombo cytopanenia, pneumonia, malaria
C. Use of aspirin, liver abscess, fever.
D. Cold, dust environment, hypertension.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Conductive and sensorineural hearing loss can be detected through different diagnostic methods like:
A. Whisper test
B. Weber test
C. Tuning folk
D. Rinne test</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Match the conditions in column A with the corresponding clinical features in column B</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Column A</p>
<ol>
<li>Hypertension</li>
<li>Rheumatic heart disease</li>
</ol>
<p>Column B
A. Lethargy, joint pain, chest pain.
B. Fever, anorexia, oedema
C. Headache, oedema, proteinuria
D. Lethargy, oedema, anorexia
E. Oedema, palpitation, anorexia
F. History of sore thorax, fever, palpitation.</p>
<p>Page 4 of 8</p>
<p>KMTC/QP-08/EPS</p>
<ol start="21">
<li>The most common causes of peritonitis are typically infections that can be either primary or secondary. These include:</li>
</ol>
<p>A. Pancreatitis, multiple trauma, idiopathic
B. Ischaemic small bowel injuries, cholecystitis, subphrenic abscess
C. Appendicitis, diverticulitis, large bowel perforation
D. Acute salpingitis, post-operative complications, heredity</p>
<ol start="22">
<li>The clinical manifestations of tonsillitis can vary depending on the cause, but common signs and symptoms include:</li>
</ol>
<p>A. Sore throat, hoarseness of voice, fever
B. Sore throat, fever, difficulty in swallowing
C. Sore throat, fever, pain
D. Sore throat, fever, headache</p>
<ol start="23">
<li>Dysmenorrhea refers to:</li>
</ol>
<p>A. Irregular menstruation
B. Heavy menstrual flow
C. Prolonged period of menstruation
D. Painful menstruation</p>
<ol start="24">

<ol>
<li>Mrs A. who is in labour appears restless and says; am not certain if am going to go through this labour without complications. The midwife’s appropriate nursing diagnosis will be;</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>A. Discomfort related to labour pains evidenced by verbalization</li>
<li>B. Anxiety related to outcome of labour evidenced by verbalisation</li>
<li>C. Knowledge deficit related to process of labour evidenced by woman asking many questions</li>
<li>D. Risk of injury related to the delivery process</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>The rationale of doing vaginal examination when the membranes rupture during first stage of labour is to;</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>A. Confirm labour</li>
<li>B. Assess the adequacy of the pelvis</li>
<li>C. Assess cervical dilatation</li>
<li>D. Rule out cord prolapse</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>The correct client education that will be given by the midwife to a pregnant mother in first stage of labour includes;</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>A. Rub the back and breath in and out during a contraction</li>
<li>B. Hold your breath and push with every contraction</li>
<li>C. Walk around when membranes rupture and push with every contraction</li>
<li>D. Rub the back and Walk around when membranes rupture</li>
</ul>
<ol start="4">
<li>History taken on time labour started, presence of show, state of membranes and strength of uterine contractions is;</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>A. Family and social</li>
<li>B. Past medical and surgical</li>
<li>C. Past obstetric</li>
<li>D. Present obstetric</li>
</ul>
<ol start="5">
<li>The true signs of labor, which indicate that your body is preparing for childbirth, include:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>A. Progressive cervical dilation and presence of show</li>
<li>B. Irregular painless uterine contraction, contraction last 3-4 minutes</li>
<li>C. Progressive cervical dilation, contraction last 3-4 minutes</li>
<li>D. Presence of show, Irregular painless uterine contraction</li>
</ul>
<ol start="6">
<li>The stage of labour that starts from when the cervix is fully dilated until the baby is delivered is considered what stage:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>A. First</li>
<li>B. Second</li>
<li>C. Third</li>
<li>D. Fourth</li>
</ul>
<ol start="7">
<li>The circular constriction or contraction ring that forms around the uterus, often between the upper and lower segments known as the Bandl’s ring is a sign of labour that is;</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>A. Obstructed</li>
<li>B. Precipitate</li>
<li>C. Prolonged</li>
<li>D. Premature</li>

<ol start="8">
<li>
<p>State if the following statements are true or false;

B. Perinium gives attachment to the muscles of the pelvic floor.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Placenta separation occurs after the baby is delivered, and the placenta detaches from the uterine wall to be expelled. The methods of placenta separation include:
A. Battledore, Shultze
B. Shultze, Matthew Duncan
C. Battledore, Velamentous
D. Matthew Duncan, Battledore,</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When examining a normal placenta after delivery, healthcare providers typically look for specific characteristics to ensure it has functioned properly during pregnancy and has been expelled correctly. Normal findings during examination of a placenta include;
A. 18-22 lobes, infarcts

C. 18-22 lobes, foetal surface is greyish white, shinny
D. Maternal surface is greyish white, shinny; Foetal surface is dark red in colour</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Lochia is the vaginal discharge that occurs after childbirth as the uterus sheds the tissue and blood that supported the pregnancy. The characteristics of a normal post-natal period lochia loss include;
A. Lochia rubra day 1-4, Profuse red lochia
B. Red lochia on day 10-14, Lochia serosa – For day 5-9
C. Lochia rubra day 1-4, Lochia serosa – For day 5-9
D. Profuse red lochia, Red lochia on day 10-14</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>To control other people by giving money for sex, giving good grades in exchange for sex, or even sexual abuse or rape refers to;
A. Sexuality
B. Sexualisation
C. Sex
D. Sexual intimacy</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When a woman assumes the knee-chest position, she kneels on the bed or floor with her hips raised, and her chest close to the ground. The midwife assists a pregnant woman to Knee-chest position during management of;

C. Obstructed labour, prolonged labour
D. prolonged labour, cord presentation</p>
</li>
<li>

</ol>
<p>KMTC/QP-08/EPS</p>
<ol start="15">

</ol>

B. Suboccipitobregmatic 9.5cm
C. Suboccipitofrontal 10cm
D. Mentovertical 13.5cm</p>
<ol start="17">

</ol>
<p>A. Regenerative
B. Proliferative
C. Secretory

</ol>
<p>A. Prolactin
B. Oestrogen
C. Oxytocinon

</ol>

<p>In assessment of the pelvic outlet, the diameter that the midwife measures by fitting four knuckles between perineum and the ischial tuberosities is;

<li>

A. Bed for at least 2-3 days, removal at 37 weeks

</li>
<li>
<p>A mother has been brought to the post-natal clinic with report of self-neglect and loss of interest in the newborn. The earliest sign of puerperal sepsis is usually;
A. Abdominal pains
B. Headache

D. Rigors</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A post-natal mother complains of increasing full and painful breasts for the last twenty-four hours. The correct intervention will be:
A. Suspend breastfeeding, empty breast by expressing milk
B. Continue breast feeding, antibiotics
C. Continue breast feeding, take milk for culture and sensitivity
D. Suspend breastfeeding, taking milk for culture and sensitivity is unnecessary</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>KMTC/QP-08/EPS</p>
<ol start="30">
<li>
<p>You are in charge of the maternity unit and a report on maternal mortality is required. The number of maternal deaths per 100,000 women of reproductive age refers to: -
A. Direct maternal deaths
B. Indirect maternal deaths
C. Maternal mortality rate
D. Maternal mortality ratio</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In occipitoposterior position (OPP), during labour when the occiput rotates 3/8th anteriorly the outcome will be;
A. Spontaneous vertex delivery
B. Deep transverse arrest
C. Face to pubes
D. Oblique diameter arrest</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A client has presented with signs of shoulder dystocia. The non-invasive manoeuvres in management of shoulder dystocia includes:
A. McRoberts, suprapubic pressure, change of maternal position
B. Suprapubic pressure, rubins manoeuvres, symphysiotomy
C. McRoberts, lovset, symphysiotomy
D. Lovset, suprapubic pressure, change of maternal position</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A midwife will recognize a mother has puerperal psychosis by observing the following;
A. Hallucinations, delusions
B. Insomnia, delusions
C. Weeping, lack of appetite
D. Hallucinations, dislike of health worker</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Preventive measures of breast engorgement include;
A. Frequent emptying of the breast, expression of milk from affected breast
B. Educate on how to breast feed, continue to breastfeed on the affected breast
C. Expose the affected breast to air, proper attachment of baby on the breast, frequent emptying of breast
D. Proper attachment of the baby on breast, frequent emptying of breasts</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>To prevent neural tube complications of the foetus, the midwife will counsel a woman during preconception period-to take:
A. Zinc
B. Ferrous sulphate
C. Iodine
D. Folic acid</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A pregnant mother reports to you that she is on HAART. Maternal risk factors of Mother to Child Transmission of HIV/AIDS that you would look out for during labour include:
A. Episiotomy, vaginal delivery, low viral load
B. Caesarian section, low viral load, Episiotomy
C. Episiotomy, vaginal delivery, low CD4 count
D. Low CD4 count, caesarian section, low viral load</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Baby P born three hours ago has been admitted in the new born unit. The characteristics of a premature baby include;
A. Skin dry and wrinkled, eyes always closed
B. Pinna of ears soft and flat, eyes always closed
C. Skin dry and wrinkled, eyes wide opened
D. Pinna of ears soft and flat, eyes wide opened</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>KMTC/QP-08/EPS</p>
<ol start="38">
<li>
<p>Weighing a newborn baby on a cold weighing scale makes the baby lose heat through;
A. Conduction
B. Evaporation
C. Convection
D. Radiation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A cardiac patient in pregnancy who experiences breathlessness with mild activities or exercise but is comfortable at rest is classified to be in grade;
A. I
B. II
C. III
D. IV</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The fetal causes for asphyxia neonatorum include;
A. Prematurity, post maturity, multiple births
B. Maternal diabetes, maternal infection, placental insufficiency
C. Preterm labour, caesarean section, prolapsed umbilical cord
D. Placental insufficiency, prolapsed umbilical cord, post maturity</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="section-2-short-answer-questions-40-marks">SECTION 2: SHORT ANSWER QUESTIONS (40 MARKS)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-2-short-answer-questions-40-marks" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="41">
<li>
<p>You have been newly posted to the labour ward and many mothers are in labour at the same time. As a midwife explain three (3) factors that determine the outcome of labour (6 Marks)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>State four (4) components of active management of 3rd stage of labour (4 Marks)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>State six (6) reproductive sexual health rights of an adolescent client (6 Marks)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Explain three (3) signs the midwife will use to diagnose actual uterine rupture in a woman with obstructed labour (6 Marks)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>While teaching novice midwives, state four (4) elements of immediate newborn care given by the midwife at the birth of a baby whose APGAR scores is 8 in 1 minute and 10 in 5 minutes that you would put emphasis on (4 Marks)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Draw a labelled diagram showing external female genitalia (6 Marks)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>While educating a couple on birth preparedness, outline four (4) advantages of Kangaroo Mother Care to the baby that you would expect them to adopt. (4 Marks)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A mother in the second stage of labour starts to push the baby and refuses to cooperate with the midwife putting the life of the baby and mother at risk. Outline four (4) risks that the midwife would be concerned about related to the mothers uncooperative behaviour (4 Marks)</p>
</li>
</ol>

After examination the midwife decides to admit the client and commence monitoring the labour and determines a spontaneous vertex delivery will take place. <div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="section-1-multiple-choice-questions">SECTION 1: MULTIPLE CHOICE QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-1-multiple-choice-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(40 MARKS)</p>
<ol>
<li>A communication style that involves expressing thoughts and feelings openly and respectfully is;</li>
</ol>
<p>A. Passive
B. Aggressive
C. Assertive
D. Submissive</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Active listening is an appropriate communication skill that implies;</li>
</ol>
<p>A. Hearing what is said without feedback
B. Nodding along to what the speaker says
C. Interrupting the speaker to seek for clarity with questions
D. Fully concentrating on the speaker, understanding and responding</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>You are assessing developmental stages and conclude older adults have reached Erickson's developmental stage of ego, integrity, when they: -</li>
</ol>
<p>A. Acknowledge that one cannot get everything one wants in life
B. Assess their lives and identify actions that have values and purpose
C. Express a wish that life could be relived differently
D. Feel that they are being punished for things they did not do</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>You are following up clients in the urban health centers to ensure they meet the primary goal of community health nursing which is;</li>
</ol>
<p>A. To support and supplement the effort of the medical profession in the promotion of health and prevention of illness.
B. To enhance the capacity of individuals, families, and communities to cope with their health needs.
C. To increase the productivity of the people by providing them with services that will increase their level of health.
D. To contribute to the national development through promotion of family welfare. Focusing particularly on the mothers and children.</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>You are determining an individual’s and family life stage and environment. A primary agent of the socialization process you may consider is;</li>
</ol>
<p>A. Laws
B. Family
C. Government
D. Economy</p>
<ol start="6">
<li>In an MCH clinic a health talk is ongoing. The health educator will be considered to be “paraphrasing” when:</li>
</ol>
<p>A. Saying exactly what the other person said
B. Ignoring the main message
C. Restating the message in their own words
D. Speaking in a different language</p>
<p>Page 2 of 8</p>
<p>KMTC/QP-08/EPS</p>
<ol start="7">
<li>
<p>Mrs. K, an elderly woman needs to limit her kcalorie intake without sacrificing needed nutrients. While keeping in mind the food pyramid, which of the following would she do?
A. Eliminate carbohydrate
B. Count kcalories and not worry about the food groups
C. Eliminate dairy foods.
D. Carefully select foods rich in nutrients but low in kcalories</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A nurse is caring for a patient experiencing dysphagia. Which interventions help decrease the risk of aspiration during feeding;
A. Sit the patient upright in a chair
B. Give liquids at the end of the meal
C. Provide thin foods to make it easier to swallow
D. Feed the patient slowly, allowing time to chew and swallow</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A parasite that is completely dependent on the host during a segment or all of its life cycle is said to be;
A. Obligate parasite
B. Erratic parasite
C. Paratenic parasite
D. Facultative parasite</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A handkerchief from a child with chickenpox is likely to be contaminated with the virus that causes chickenpox (varicella zoster virus). The handkerchief in this case plays the role of a;
A. Host
B. Fomite
C. Pathogen
D. Vector</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>While feeding on a blood meal of a susceptible mammalian host, an infected tsetse fly (Glossina palpalis) injects;
A. Mesenteric amastigotes
B. Lymphatic amastigotes
C. Metacyclic trypomastigotes
D. Blood stream trypomastigotes</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A process by which a community is made alert of its problems and the available resources, such as, manpower, money, materials, ideas and time is community refers to;
A. Sensitization
B. Awareness
C. Mobilization
D. Participation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>You are organizing a feeding program for special needs communities. An Act of the Kenyan parliament that prescribes food safety is;
A. Nurses act CAP 257
B. Public health Act CAP 242
C. Clinical officers act CAP 241
D. Medical practitioners act CAP 253</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Page 3 of 8</p>
<p>KMTC/QP-08/EPS</p>
<ol start="14">
<li>
<p>A community health nurse fails in their professional duty to care leading to harm on the patient. They are liable for:
A. Dereliction
B. Negligence
C. Malpractice
D. Misunderstanding</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Baby Kay is brought to your facility for immunization at the age of ten (10) weeks. Vaccines that you are likely to administer to the infant include:
A. Measles, BCG, rotavirus vaccine
B. Vitamin A, oral polio 2(OPV 2), pneumococcal
C. Oral Polio (OPV 2), pneumococcal, pentavalent 2
D. Inactivated polio vaccine (IPV), measles, hepatitis B</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The right sequence in the KEPI logistic management cycle is: -
A. Estimate the vaccine requirement, order vaccines, receive vaccines, store vaccines, issue and use
B. Estimate vaccine requirements, issue and use, order vaccines, receive vaccines, store vaccines
C. Receive vaccines, issue and use, estimate vaccine requirements, order vaccine, receive vaccines
D. Receive vaccines, order vaccines, issue and use, estimate vaccine requirements to store vaccines</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A 30 year old lady has opted to take oral contraceptivves as her FP method. The mode of action of combined oral contraceptive includes:
A. Ovulation inhibition, thickening of mucus
B. Slippery mucus, delayed ovulation
C. Slowed motility, enhanced ovulation
D. Increased motility in uterine tubes, thickening of endometrium</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A method of family planning that involves recording body temperature while observing changes in the cervical mucus is:
A. Fertility awareness method
B. Symptom-thermal method
C. Lactation amenorrhea method
D. Basal Body Temperature method</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>You are a health care worker assigned to carry out community mobilization. Resources that you will target include:
A. Money, land, materials, manpower
B. Money, materials, time, manpower.
C. Community participation, time, manpower.
D. Community participation, money and land.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>KMTC/QP-08/EPS</p>
<ol start="20">
<li>
<p>As a provider of home based care services you are expected to uphold a principle of ethical reasoning that allows client assume the right to make own decisions about their health. This is in line with the principle of: -
A. Veracity
B. Fidelity
C. Autonomy
D. Paternalism</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A nurse is teaching a client with genital herpes. Education for this client should include an explanation of:
A. Why the disease is transmittable only when visible lesions are present
B. The need for the use of petroleum products.
C. Option of disregarding safer-sex practices now that he's already infected.
D. The importance of informing the sexual partners of the disease.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>While caring for a patient with a sexually transmitted infection (STI), the most appropriate nursing intervention to provide emotional support to a patient will be to;
A. Use concerned listening when the patient expresses negative feelings.
B. Reassure the patient that the disease is curable with appropriate treatment.
C. Offer many alternatives that the patient can use to change sexual relationships.
D. Help the patient who is an innocent sexual partner forgive the infecting partner.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>While carrying out community health programs a nurse is expected to also test whether the expected outcome has been achieved. This activity is refers to;
A. Assessment
B. Planning
C. Implementation
D. Evaluation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The second life cycle cohort in the Kenya Essential Package for Health covers: -
A. 2 weeks to 5 years of life
B. 6 years to 12 years of life
C. From 14 - 28 days to cover full neonatal period
D. Pregnancy and newborn up to 28 days of life</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In construction of living quarters, the biological criteria for an adequate house aims at: -
A. Providing security for the occupants
B. Facilitating effective family functioning
C. Minimizing the risk of disease transmission
D. Fostering healthy child upbringing</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>You are caring for a patient with tuberculosis in HIV. The patient is to be on pyridoxine throughout the course of treatment in order to;
A. Prevent visual disturbances
B. Prevent peripheral neuropathy
C. Treat other opportunistic infections
D. Prevent drug toxicities</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>KMTC/QP-08/EPS</p>
<ol start="27">
<li>
<p>Symptoms in stage 2 of WHO clinical staging of HIV/AIDS for adults include: -
A. Herpes zoster, seborrheic dermatitis
B. Oral candidiasis, pulmonary TB
C. Thrombocytopenia, pyomyositis
D. Neutropenia, sinusitis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>During your home visiting, a client with stage 2 cancer expresses that, “If I can just live long enough to attend my son’s graduation, I’ll be ready to die”. Which phrase of coping with death is the client expressing:
A. Anger
B. Denial
C. Depression
D. Bargaining</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Individuals under the age of majority who are self-supporting and no longer require parental consent for health care are referred to as: -
A. Mature minors
B. Incompetent minors
C. Superior minors
D. Emancipated minors</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A mental health nurse asks a psychiatric patient for their three names, name of the hospital they are in and the month of the year. The nurse will be assessing the patient for;
A. Perception
B. Attention
C. Abstraction
D. Orientation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>While managing a patient on antipsychotics, you observe that the patient has developed sustained contraction of neck, mouth, tongue and other muscles. This side effect is known as;
A. Torticolis
B. Akathisia
C. Acute dystonia
D. Tardive dyskinesia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The major reason as to why milieu therapy is a good mode of treatment for antisocial personality disorders is: -
A. Provides a system for punishment and rewards for behavior modification.
B. Emulates a social community in which the patient may learn to live harmoniously with others.
C. Provides mostly one to one interaction between the patient and the therapist.
D. Provides a very structured setting which the patients have very little input into the planning of their care.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>KMTC/QP-08/EPS</p>
<ol start="33">
<li>
<p>In the multi axial assessment of mentally ill persons, general medical conditions are classified under;
A. Axis I
B. Axis II
C. Axis III
D. Axis IV</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>While sharing health messages on sources of water, as a nurse you will inform the community that sources of ground water include: -
A. Ponds, rivers, shallow wells
B. Springs, deep wells, rivers
C. Rivers, springs, ponds
D. Springs, shallow wells, deep wells</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Political commitment plays an important role in the success of Primary Health Care (PHC) issues because it is involved with: -
A. Implementation of issues
B. Policy issues affecting health
C. Planning of health project
D. Organization of health workers</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A number of families in village X have been diagnosed to be suffering from malnutrition. External factors that influence family health include: -
A. Family size, family structure, family locality.
B. Family locality, biological characteristics, climate
C. Family values, family members, family structure.
D. Family locality, land terrain, climatic condition,</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cases of cervical cancer have been diagnosed in school B. Educating teenage girls on need for regular cervical cancer screening as an example of;
A. Secondary prevention
B. Primary prevention
C. Primordial prevention
D. Tertiary prevention.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For this question, indicate whether the given statements are TRUE or FALSE
i. Advocacy is a process, which enables people to put their efforts together for carrying out the joint activities unifying resources and building solidarity
ii. The community should make an action plan during community dialogue, and the action plan is implemented on the Action day</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>You are endeavoring to create the greatest impact in a community and hope to produce lasting change that promotes healthy behavior. As a nurse you should: -
A. Talk to patients about needing to quit smoking
B. Talk to patients about losing weight
C. Create supportive environments that will reinforce good health practices
D. Decide for the patients and give best solution for the patient</p>
</li>
</ol>

<p>A. Antenatal kit, family folder, anesthetic kit

C. Community bag, family folder, health education materials

<ol>
<li>
<p>Leucorrhea is a cardinal sign of the following eye conditions
a) Cataracts
b) Keratitis
c) Conjunctivitis
d) Retinoblerstoma</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Which of the following statements best describes psoriasis
a) Is a type one hypersensitivity disorder
b) An inflammation of the deep dermal and subcutaneous tissues
c) A chronic non-infectious inflammatory disease of the skin
d) A serious autoimmune disease of the skin and mucous membrane</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A patient with a calculi in the gall bladder is said to have
a) Choledochotomy
b) Choledocholiathiasis
c) Cholelithiasis
d) Cholecystitis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The main goal of nursing care of a patient in PACU include
a) Normal vital signs, bowel sounds have returned
b) Blood is running well, patient has passed urine
c) Vital signs are stable, absence of hemorrhage
d) Absence of hemorrhage, absence of infection</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Bad dreams, delirium and hallucinations are side effects of
a) Morphine sulphate
b) Suxamethonium
c) Ketamine hydrochloride
d) Thiopentone</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The innermost layer of the meninges of the spinal cord is the
a) Arachnoid mater
b) Subarachnoid mater
c) Dura mater
d) Pia matter</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The major causes of pyelonephritis include
a) Pseudomonas euroginosa
b) Streptococcus aureus
c) Mycobacterium tuberculi
d) Escherichia coli</p>
</li>
</ol>

</li>
<li>
<p>The blood pressure readings that indicate stage 1 hypertension are
a) Systolic 140 – 149, diastolic 90 – 99 MmHg
b) Systolic 150 – 159, diastolic 100 – 110 MmHg
c) Systolic 100 – 120, diastolic 60 – 80 MmHg
d) Systolic 120 – 139, diastolic 80 – 89 MmHg</p>
</li>
<li>

</li>

</li>

</li>

</li>
<li>

</li>

<ol>
<li>
<p>Leucorrhea is a cardinal sign of the following eye conditions
a) Cataracts
b) Keratitis
c) Conjunctivitis
d) Retinoblerstoma</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Which of the following statements best describes psoriasis
a) Is a type one hypersensitivity disorder
b) An inflammation of the deep dermal and subcutaneous tissues
c) A chronic non-infectious inflammatory disease of the skin
d) A serious autoimmune disease of the skin and mucous membrane</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A patient with a calculi in the gall bladder is said to have
a) Choledochotomy
b) Choledocholiathiasis
c) Cholelithiasis
d) Cholecystitis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The main goal of nursing care of a patient in PACU include
a) Normal vital signs, bowel sounds have returned
b) Blood is running well, patient has passed urine
c) Vital signs are stable, absence of hemorrhage
d) Absence of hemorrhage, absence of infection</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Bad dreams, delirium and hallucinations are side effects of
a) Morphine sulphate
b) Suxamethonium
c) Ketamine hydrochloride
d) Thiopentone</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The innermost layer of the meninges of the spinal cord is the
a) Arachnoid mater
b) Subarachnoid mater
c) Dura mater
d) Pia matter</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The major causes of pyelonephritis include
a) Pseudomonas euroginosa
b) Streptococcus aureus
c) Mycobacterium tuberculi
d) Escherichia coli</p>
</li>
</ol>

</li>
<li>
<p>The blood pressure readings that indicate stage 1 hypertension are
a) Systolic 140 – 149, diastolic 90 – 99 MmHg
b) Systolic 150 – 159, diastolic 100 – 110 MmHg
c) Systolic 100 – 120, diastolic 60 – 80 MmHg
d) Systolic 120 – 139, diastolic 80 – 89 MmHg</p>
</li>
<li>

a) An increase in chest hair
b) Testicular hypertrophy
c) An increased clothing tendency
d) Muscle wasting</p>
</li>

c) Congestive heart failure
d) Rheumatoid arthritis</p>
</li>
<li>

b) Age
c) Contacts of the casualty
d) Life threatening situations</p>
</li>
<li>

b) Auscultation, Inspection, Palpation, Percussion

d) Palpation, Inspection, Percussion, Auscultation</p>
</li>
<li>

</li>
<li>

</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="section-1-multiple-choice-questions-40-marks">SECTION 1: MULTIPLE CHOICE QUESTIONS (40 MARKS)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-1-multiple-choice-questions-40-marks" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Developmental tasks of a launching centre family include: -
a) Child socialization
b) Cultivating leisure time activities
c) Releasing children as young adults
d) Open parent-child communication</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A process by which a community is made alert of its problems and the available resources, such as, manpower, money, materials, ideas and time is community;
a) Sensitization
b) Awareness
c) Mobilization
d) Participation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The ability of a person to make and maintain acceptable interactions with other people in a community is:-
a) Physical health
b) Mental health
c) Social health
d) Emotional health</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Preventive health services offered at a MCH/FP clinic include;
a) Exercises, good nutritional practises, personal hygiene,
b) Growth monitoring and screening, breast examination
c) Diagnosis and treatment of minor ailments and referral
d) Immunization, health education, antenatal and postnatal care</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Functions of the division of family health included in the county department of health are :-
a) Referral and ambulance, health facilities, mental health
b) Occupational health, waste management, vector control
c) Nutritional services, expanded program of immunization, adolescent health
d) Infrastructure and maintenance, procurement, health facility management</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The following Act of the Kenyan laws prescribes food safety;
a) Nurses act CAP 257
b) Public health Act CAP 242
c) Clinical officers act CAP 241
d) Medical practitioners act CAP 253</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The role of a community health nurse that involves advising other health care providers on the needs of the community is;
a) Planner
b) Manager
c) Advocator
d) Educator</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The following vaccines are administered to infants at ten (10) weeks;
a) Measles, BCG, rotavirus vaccine
b) Vitamin A, oral polio 2(OPV 2), pneumococcal
c) Oral Polio (OPV 2), pneumococcal, pentavalent 2
d) Inactivated polio vaccine (IPV), measles, hepatitis B</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Page 3 of 7</p>
<p>KMTC/QP-08/EPS</p>
<ol start="9">
<li>
<p>The following is used to measure success in health education process;
a) Changes in behavior and attitudes.
b) The ability to incorporate advance technology
c) The willingness of all stakeholders to support the program.
d) The attentiveness of the audience during health education.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A concept of Primary Health Care (PHC) that ensures rural health services are provided by methods that are within the social cultural norms of a community is:-
a) Accessibility
b) Affordability
c) Availability
d) Acceptability</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The following are additional elements of primary health care (PHC) added by the Kenyan government;
a) Education, nutrition, local disease control, malaria control
b) Mental health, dental health, community based rehabilitation, malaria control
c) Family planning, expanded programme of immunization, essential drug supply, local disease control
d) Community based rehabilitation, safe water supply, nutrition and adequate food supply, mental health</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Resources targeted during Community mobilization include the following;
a) Money, land, materials, manpower
b) Money, materials, time, manpower.
c) Community participation, time, manpower.
d) Community participation, money and land.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Level one health care delivery in Kenya is provided by.
a) The family and community members.
b) The enrolment community health workers
c) Trained public health nurses
d) Traditional birth attendants.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The drug of choice in the treatment of schistosomiasis is;
a) Praziquantel 40mg/kg body weight as a single dose
b) Metronidazole tabs 400mg tds x5/7
c) Amphotericin B 3mg/kg body weight for 10days
d) Amoxicillin caps 500mg tds x5/7</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Incubation period is;
a) The time of infection and death
b) Appearance of clinical symptoms and death
c) Time of infection and appearance of antibodies
d) The time of infection and appearance of clinical symptoms</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The correct stages in the progression of measles are:-
a) Prodromal phase, eruptive phase, post-measles phase
b) Pre-measles phase, prodromal phase, post-measles phase
c) Pre-measles phase, eruptive phase, post-measles phase
d) Eruptive phase, pre-measles phase, post-measles phase</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Page 3 of 7</p>
<p>KMTC/QP-08/EPS</p>
<ol start="17">
<li>
<p>Environmental factors whose effects are commonly expressed as stress, depression, hysteria are;
a) Chemical hazards
b) Physical hazards
c) Psychological hazards
d) Biological hazards</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>You are a Nurse working with local NGO and you have been assigned to conduct community dialogue in village X. What will be your first action?
a) Meet with the local leaders in the village
b) Develop and action plan
c) Do a transect walk in the village
d) Prioritize community needs</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The following preventive/promotive services are appropriate to Late Childhood (6-12 yrs) cohort.
a) Antenatal care, breastfeeding
b) Vaccination, growth monitoring
c) Supplementary feeding, de-worming
d) Nutritional care, insecticide treated net use</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The fundamental learning process aimed at changing behaviour and attitude with respect to health practices thus involves family individual and community is :-
a) Health analysis
b) Health education
c) Health promotion
d) Family counseling</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Voluntary action in health education is;
a) The process of creating favorable conditions for learning in the community ☑
b) An interactive process aimed at changing behavior specific messages and different communication approaches
c) The taking up behavioral measures by a person to achieve an intended health effect with full understanding and acceptance of purposes
d) The process of sharing ideas, information, knowledge, and experience among people for behavior change</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Health promotion implies;
a) Offering curative services to the community
b) Detecting diseases in good time
c) Enabling people to increase control over their heath
d) Averting diseases in specific populations</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The correct sequence of activities during community diagnosis is;
a) Planning of the survey, exploration, pretesting survey tools, report writing, dissemination and community action
b) Exploration, planning of the survey, pretesting survey tools, report writing, dissemination and community actions
c) Pretesting survey tools, planning of the survey, exploration, report writing, dissemination and community action
d) Exploration, pretesting survey tools, planning of the survey, report writing, dissemination and community action.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Page 4 of 7</p>
<p>KMTC/QP-08/EPS</p>
<ol start="24">
<li>Which of the following participatory methods would best be used to get information from the opinion leaders in the community?</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Focus group discussion
b) Transect walk
c) Seasonal calendars
d) Key informant interviews</p>
<ol start="25">
<li>A rural health unit under the Ministry of health that is charged with the responsibility of providing services to a particular catchment area is;</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Clinic
b) Dispensary
c) Health centre
d) Sub-county hospital</p>
<ol start="26">
<li>The principle of ethical reasoning that allows a home based care client to assume the right to make own decisions about their health is :-</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Veracity
b) Fidelity
c) Autonomy
d) Paternalism</p>
<ol start="27">
<li>The mode of action for combined oral contraceptive is;</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Ovulation inhibition, thickening of mucus
b) Slippery mucus, delayed ovulation
c) Slowed motility, enhanced ovulation
d) Increased motility in uterine tubes, thickening of endometrium</p>
<ol start="28">
<li>The following family planning method involves recording body temperature with observing cervical mucus;</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Fertility awareness method
b) Symptom-thermal method
c) Lactation amenorrhea method
d) Basal Body Temperature method</p>
<ol start="29">
<li>A nurse is teaching a client with genital herpes. Education for this client should include an explanation of</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Why the disease is transmittable only when visible lesions are present
b) The need for the use of petroleum products.
c) Option of disregarding safer-sex practices now that he's already infected.
d) The importance of informing his partners of the disease.</p>
<ol start="30">
<li>An appropriate nursing intervention to provide emotional support to a patient with an STD is to;</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Use concerned listening when the patient expresses negative feelings.
b) Reassure the patient that the disease is curable with appropriate treatment.
c) Offer many alternatives that the patient can use to change sexual relationships.
d) Help the patient who is an innocent sexual partner forgive the infecting partner.</p>
<p>Page 5 of 7</p>
<p>KMTC/QP-08/EPS</p>
<ol start="31">
<li>The ability of a disease causing agent to penetrate, multiply and produce some detectable change (establish itself) in the host is;</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Infectivity
b) Stability
c) Virulence
d) Pathogenicity</p>
<ol start="32">
<li>A therapeutic intervention applied on mentally ill persons that involves exposing the patient to dreaded or fearful stimuli while preventing avoidant behavior is;</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Flooding
b) Desensitization
c) Modeling
d) Reattribution</p>
<ol start="33">
<li>The abnormal sexual behavior in which a man fantasizes having sex with a woman whom he has been observing undress is</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Exhibitionism
b) Voyeurism
c) Frotteurism
d) Transvestitism</p>
<ol start="34">
<li>A mental health nurse who asks a psychiatric patient for their three names, name of the hospital they are in and the month of the year will be assessing for;</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Perception
b) Attention
c) Abstraction
d) Orientation</p>
<ol start="35">
<li>A statistical measure in which the numerator is not related to the denominator is: -</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Rate
b) Ratio
c) Proportion
d) Percentage</p>
<ol start="36">
<li>The persistent occurrence of a disease at a low to moderate level in a community is known as: -</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Pandemic level
b) Sporadic level
c) Endemic level
d) Epidemic level</p>
<ol start="37">
<li>A step in community health nursing programs that involves testing whether the expected outcome has been achieved is?</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Planning
b) Evaluation
c) Assessment
d) Implementation</p>
<ol start="38">
<li>Which of the following approaches is likely to be most effective for a school nurse to use in working with families in a respectful and nondiscriminatory manner?</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Being professional and sensitive to factors related to socioeconomic, ethnic, and cultural backgrounds
b) Attempting to discover pertinent characteristics of families' backgrounds before meeting with them</p>
<p>Page 6 of 7</p>
<p>KMTC/QP-08/EPS</p>
<p>c) Acknowledging obvious differences in background right away and using humor to put families at ease
d) Remaining friendly and curious while asking specific questions about families' backgrounds and living situations</p>
<ol start="39">
<li>
<p>Screening in school health services involves;
a) Treatment of the sick school children
b) Taking note of any unusual signs or symptoms
c) Referral of sick pupils for further treatment
d) Health examination to determine the pupil’s health status</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For this question, indicate whether the given statements are TRUE or FALSE
(i) Adequate community involvement is the reason why most projects in the community fails to continue when the donor funding is withdrawn
(ii) Sufficient political commitment has demonstrated movement toward attainment of health for all in developing countries</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="section-2-short-answer-questions-40-marks">SECTION 2: SHORT ANSWER QUESTIONS (40 MARKS)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-2-short-answer-questions-40-marks" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="41">
<li>Outline five (5) components of the high priority package according to the Kenya Essential Package of Health (KEPH) (5 marks)</li>
<li>Outline four (4) characteristics of a healthy community (4 marks)</li>
<li>State four (4) ways through which home accidents can be prevented in the family (4 marks)</li>
<li>Explain three (3) portals of entry of disease causing agents into the human body (6 marks)</li>
<li>Outline five (5) factors that influence nutrition status of a community (5 marks)</li>
<li>Outline five (5) features of avoidant personality disorder (5 marks)</li>
<li>Explain three (3) roles of a community health nurse in the prevention of Covid-19 disease (5 marks)</li>
<li>State five (5) factors than can hinder effective community participation (5 marks)</li>
</ol>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="section-1-multiple-choice-questions-40-marks">SECTION 1: MULTIPLE CHOICE QUESTIONS (40 MARKS)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-1-multiple-choice-questions-40-marks" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Developmental tasks of a launching centre family include: -
a) Child socialization
b) Cultivating leisure time activities
c) Releasing children as young adults
d) Open parent-child communication</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A process by which a community is made alert of its problems and the available resources, such as, manpower, money, materials, ideas and time is community;
a) Sensitization
b) Awareness
c) Mobilization
d) Participation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The ability of a person to make and maintain acceptable interactions with other people in a community is:-
a) Physical health
b) Mental health
c) Social health
d) Emotional health</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Preventive health services offered at a MCH/FP clinic include;
a) Exercises, good nutritional practises, personal hygiene,
b) Growth monitoring and screening, breast examination
c) Diagnosis and treatment of minor ailments and referral
d) Immunization, health education, antenatal and postnatal care</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Functions of the division of family health included in the county department of health are :-
a) Referral and ambulance, health facilities, mental health
b) Occupational health, waste management, vector control
c) Nutritional services, expanded program of immunization, adolescent health
d) Infrastructure and maintenance, procurement, health facility management</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The following Act of the Kenyan laws prescribes food safety;
a) Nurses act CAP 257
b) Public health Act CAP 242
c) Clinical officers act CAP 241
d) Medical practitioners act CAP 253</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The role of a community health nurse that involves advising other health care providers on the needs of the community is;
a) Planner
b) Manager
c) Advocator
d) Educator</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The following vaccines are administered to infants at ten (10) weeks;
a) Measles, BCG, rotavirus vaccine
b) Vitamin A, oral polio 2(OPV 2), pneumococcal
c) Oral Polio (OPV 2), pneumococcal, pentavalent 2
d) Inactivated polio vaccine (IPV), measles, hepatitis B</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Page 3 of 7</p>
<p>KMTC/QP-08/EPS</p>
<ol start="9">
<li>
<p>The following is used to measure success in health education process;
a) Changes in behavior and attitudes.
b) The ability to incorporate advance technology
c) The willingness of all stakeholders to support the program.
d) The attentiveness of the audience during health education.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A concept of Primary Health Care (PHC) that ensures rural health services are provided by methods that are within the social cultural norms of a community is:-
a) Accessibility
b) Affordability
c) Availability
d) Acceptability</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The following are additional elements of primary health care (PHC) added by the Kenyan government;
a) Education, nutrition, local disease control, malaria control
b) Mental health, dental health, community based rehabilitation, malaria control
c) Family planning, expanded programme of immunization, essential drug supply, local disease control
d) Community based rehabilitation, safe water supply, nutrition and adequate food supply, mental health</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Resources targeted during Community mobilization include the following;
a) Money, land, materials, manpower
b) Money, materials, time, manpower.
c) Community participation, time, manpower.
d) Community participation, money and land.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Level one health care delivery in Kenya is provided by.
a) The family and community members.
b) The enrolment community health workers
c) Trained public health nurses
d) Traditional birth attendants.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The drug of choice in the treatment of schistosomiasis is;
a) Praziquantel 40mg/kg body weight as a single dose
b) Metronidazole tabs 400mg tds x5/7
c) Amphotericin B 3mg/kg body weight for 10days
d) Amoxicillin caps 500mg tds x5/7</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Incubation period is;
a) The time of infection and death
b) Appearance of clinical symptoms and death
c) Time of infection and appearance of antibodies
d) The time of infection and appearance of clinical symptoms</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The correct stages in the progression of measles are:-
a) Prodromal phase, eruptive phase, post-measles phase
b) Pre-measles phase, prodromal phase, post-measles phase
c) Pre-measles phase, eruptive phase, post-measles phase
d) Eruptive phase, pre-measles phase, post-measles phase</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Page 3 of 7</p>
<p>KMTC/QP-08/EPS</p>
<ol start="17">
<li>
<p>Environmental factors whose effects are commonly expressed as stress, depression, hysteria are;
a) Chemical hazards
b) Physical hazards
c) Psychological hazards
d) Biological hazards</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>You are a Nurse working with local NGO and you have been assigned to conduct community dialogue in village X. What will be your first action?
a) Meet with the local leaders in the village
b) Develop and action plan
c) Do a transect walk in the village
d) Prioritize community needs</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The following preventive/promotive services are appropriate to Late Childhood (6-12 yrs) cohort.
a) Antenatal care, breastfeeding
b) Vaccination, growth monitoring
c) Supplementary feeding, de-worming
d) Nutritional care, insecticide treated net use</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The fundamental learning process aimed at changing behaviour and attitude with respect to health practices thus involves family individual and community is :-
a) Health analysis
b) Health education
c) Health promotion
d) Family counseling</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Voluntary action in health education is;
a) The process of creating favorable conditions for learning in the community ☑
b) An interactive process aimed at changing behavior specific messages and different communication approaches
c) The taking up behavioral measures by a person to achieve an intended health effect with full understanding and acceptance of purposes
d) The process of sharing ideas, information, knowledge, and experience among people for behavior change</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Health promotion implies;
a) Offering curative services to the community
b) Detecting diseases in good time
c) Enabling people to increase control over their heath
d) Averting diseases in specific populations</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The correct sequence of activities during community diagnosis is;
a) Planning of the survey, exploration, pretesting survey tools, report writing, dissemination and community action
b) Exploration, planning of the survey, pretesting survey tools, report writing, dissemination and community actions
c) Pretesting survey tools, planning of the survey, exploration, report writing, dissemination and community action
d) Exploration, pretesting survey tools, planning of the survey, report writing, dissemination and community action.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Page 4 of 7</p>
<p>KMTC/QP-08/EPS</p>
<ol start="24">
<li>Which of the following participatory methods would best be used to get information from the opinion leaders in the community?</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Focus group discussion
b) Transect walk
c) Seasonal calendars
d) Key informant interviews</p>
<ol start="25">
<li>A rural health unit under the Ministry of health that is charged with the responsibility of providing services to a particular catchment area is;</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Clinic
b) Dispensary
c) Health centre
d) Sub-county hospital</p>
<ol start="26">
<li>The principle of ethical reasoning that allows a home based care client to assume the right to make own decisions about their health is :-</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Veracity
b) Fidelity
c) Autonomy
d) Paternalism</p>
<ol start="27">
<li>The mode of action for combined oral contraceptive is;</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Ovulation inhibition, thickening of mucus
b) Slippery mucus, delayed ovulation
c) Slowed motility, enhanced ovulation
d) Increased motility in uterine tubes, thickening of endometrium</p>
<ol start="28">
<li>The following family planning method involves recording body temperature with observing cervical mucus;</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Fertility awareness method
b) Symptom-thermal method
c) Lactation amenorrhea method
d) Basal Body Temperature method</p>
<ol start="29">
<li>A nurse is teaching a client with genital herpes. Education for this client should include an explanation of</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Why the disease is transmittable only when visible lesions are present
b) The need for the use of petroleum products.
c) Option of disregarding safer-sex practices now that he's already infected.
d) The importance of informing his partners of the disease.</p>
<ol start="30">
<li>An appropriate nursing intervention to provide emotional support to a patient with an STD is to;</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Use concerned listening when the patient expresses negative feelings.
b) Reassure the patient that the disease is curable with appropriate treatment.
c) Offer many alternatives that the patient can use to change sexual relationships.
d) Help the patient who is an innocent sexual partner forgive the infecting partner.</p>
<p>Page 5 of 7</p>
<p>KMTC/QP-08/EPS</p>
<ol start="31">
<li>The ability of a disease causing agent to penetrate, multiply and produce some detectable change (establish itself) in the host is;</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Infectivity
b) Stability
c) Virulence
d) Pathogenicity</p>
<ol start="32">
<li>A therapeutic intervention applied on mentally ill persons that involves exposing the patient to dreaded or fearful stimuli while preventing avoidant behavior is;</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Flooding
b) Desensitization
c) Modeling
d) Reattribution</p>
<ol start="33">
<li>The abnormal sexual behavior in which a man fantasizes having sex with a woman whom he has been observing undress is</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Exhibitionism
b) Voyeurism
c) Frotteurism
d) Transvestitism</p>
<ol start="34">
<li>A mental health nurse who asks a psychiatric patient for their three names, name of the hospital they are in and the month of the year will be assessing for;</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Perception
b) Attention
c) Abstraction
d) Orientation</p>
<ol start="35">
<li>A statistical measure in which the numerator is not related to the denominator is: -</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Rate
b) Ratio
c) Proportion
d) Percentage</p>
<ol start="36">
<li>The persistent occurrence of a disease at a low to moderate level in a community is known as: -</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Pandemic level
b) Sporadic level
c) Endemic level
d) Epidemic level</p>
<ol start="37">
<li>A step in community health nursing programs that involves testing whether the expected outcome has been achieved is?</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Planning
b) Evaluation
c) Assessment
d) Implementation</p>
<ol start="38">
<li>Which of the following approaches is likely to be most effective for a school nurse to use in working with families in a respectful and nondiscriminatory manner?</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Being professional and sensitive to factors related to socioeconomic, ethnic, and cultural backgrounds
b) Attempting to discover pertinent characteristics of families' backgrounds before meeting with them</p>
<p>Page 6 of 7</p>
<p>KMTC/QP-08/EPS</p>
<p>c) Acknowledging obvious differences in background right away and using humor to put families at ease
d) Remaining friendly and curious while asking specific questions about families' backgrounds and living situations</p>
<ol start="39">
<li>
<p>Screening in school health services involves;
a) Treatment of the sick school children
b) Taking note of any unusual signs or symptoms
c) Referral of sick pupils for further treatment
d) Health examination to determine the pupil’s health status</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For this question, indicate whether the given statements are TRUE or FALSE
(i) Adequate community involvement is the reason why most projects in the community fails to continue when the donor funding is withdrawn
(ii) Sufficient political commitment has demonstrated movement toward attainment of health for all in developing countries</p>
</li>
</ol>
